SENT.plain: The authors report a case of unilateral moyamoya disease which developed into moyamoya disease 3 years later
Unilateral moyamoya disease is generally defined as moyamoya disease, but the exact relationship is unknown
In this case, occlusive changes developed in the stenotic carotid fork, and in a similar portion contralaterally which was intact
Follow-up 4-vessel angiography is strongly recommended even for unilateral moyamoya disease
